Robert: I never got the chance to "Thank You" for believing in me and your offer of help. My bad. So thank you.

RIP: Robert C. Hermann (April 28, 1931 – February 10, 2020)
Maverick and Likely discoverer of the Geometric Basis of the Quantum Field Theory of the Standard Model.

A missed moment. I was too scared to leave the damned university system behind me with all of its rules and enforced rituals. I knew what he represented: freedom, genius and irrelevancy except for the tiny number of people at the absolute top of the field.

I was too cowardly.

It simultaneously filled me with fear & hope. This odd man was not a nut or lunatic. I had spoken to a true maverick & he had seen me like no one else...even beyond my good friend Is Singer. Years later I tried to contact him but he was in an old age home with dementia. All lost.

This odd man, working outside the University system, outside Peer Review, and outside normal publishing was held in awe by the TOP Mathematician at MIT. The system knew who it had lost and revered him as a serious mind; a man with a viable claim to an earth shattering discovery.

I told Is "I know him from an enormous number of self-published books only" Then the great MIT Professor said: "Eric, that is the first man to figure out that quantum field theory is based on the geometry of Fiber Bundles before Simons, Wu, Yang & I did our work."

I was floored.

His name was Robert Hermann. I couldn't tell what was going on. He was very excited & wanted to be of any help possible. It was almost terrifying as I was not eager to discuss the work. When I told Singer about it, Singer said "That's a high compliment. Do you know who that is?"

text:
We need to end the current system. Either fund it properly again on US scale expectation, or pull the plug. 

The deep problem with Academic espionage is that we‘re trying not to pay for research. You can bitch as much as you want. But until we pay true costs, this will continue.

The idea of requiring K-12, four years of undergraduate, 5-7 years of graduate labor, 4 years of post-doctoral labor, and perhaps 6 years of tenure track before getting a permanent job is beyond psychotic. That could be 30 years of constant preparation for a first permanent job.

The solution may be to fund the very people who are causing the problem at a US market level of stability & ease that hasn’t been seen in 50 years. That feels awful to me. But you won’t be able to stop this problem with every researcher worrying about grants, labor, tenure, etc.

In short, universities fashion an idealism about a post-national world that is the exact shape of a well placed fig-leaf to cover the needs for funding underfunded science. The rationalization precisely matches the need to make up the shortfall. The solution is thus paradoxical.

The biggest problem with this is that other nations remain nations. China isn’t post-national. Oil kingdoms aren’t post-national. South Asia isn’t. Nor is Russia.

By underfunding science we opened the door to a “post-national delusion” which spread to justify funding research.

text:
Also, there is nowhere I expect more lies than public health and safety. It seems to be part of the public health playbook and must be taught in MPH school.

The weird highly conserved phrase to look for? 

“The Public was Never in Any Danger.” as well as all its variants.

In short, the best we can usually do is map instutional silence and media under-reporting from a baseline. Here, the *minimal* baseline possible story is panic based on misinterpreted images. When something like that goes underreported, it’s usually a major clue something is off.

I‘m noticing a disconnect as well. Since I know very little about this, here’s what I generally do: watch for any disconnect between images & reported news.

If they’re fake, that’s a news story. If they are misinterpreted, that too is a news story. Then ask “Where is that news?” https://t.co/PImlPSdmuB

entity.description: Presenter Alan Yentob explores the world of the arts, not just in Britain but around the globe. But it's a broad definition of the arts. Episodes contain interviews with or about popular music acts like Simon and Garfunkel, U2 and the Rolling Stones. But others include a discussion of Van Goh's works or a tribute to playwright Simon Gray. Still others examine topics like the lost art of oratory, the art of stand-up comedy, the music of Rajasthan, the life of photographer Annie Leibovitz or the history of the guitar. It's an eclectic yet artistic mix of topics.

text:
How could something exist and the internet not know it? To this day I don’t think Spotify has it.

But then, I checked back in.

And there it was...and exactly as it was in my mind. Someone actually had to video a turntable playing it!

I hope you like it: https://t.co/BZRTsfY0hD

Then I would be assured that our “minds play tricks”. That “Memory is a funny thing” and that “You should be happy that your imagination came up with a song you like!” All very understanding. Eventually this made me feel crazy. How could that be?!? 
So, many years ago, I gave up.

In my mind, it was called “Standing on the Corner” and it was uptempo & put me in a good mood. I thought it was sung by Chris Youlden. But all references went to the Four Lads. Or Dean Martin. People would assure me that was the song. But I couldn’t accept that. That song sucked!

Sometimes you think you remember something but you can’t find reference to it. No one else seems to remember it. You start to doubt yourself. Hard. “Did I invent that? Is that a figment of my imagination? Am I lying?”

This happened to me with a song. I couldn’t find it anywhere.
@PamelaParesky https://t.co/wZl1Plc1Xq

This primary season: #SlipTheDISC

Learn the role that Perseveration & Ridicule play in controlling us at scale. This is one of the most important cognitive self-defense videos I’ve ever seen.

Don’t fear corporate or anonymous ridicule if you’re right:
https://t.co/e7XeNGJ7ez

Almost every research university shows the same pattern:

A) Sky high tuition increases
B) Huge increases in administrators
C) Decrease in permanent faculty
D) Foreign labor hired as ‘students’
E) Near certainty it’s president was born before 1964.

It’s the best joke. At scale.

We‘re now in our 20th year of US presidents born in the summer of 1946 at the very *beginning* of the baby boom with 8 more years of a boomer president born later with 4 more years likely. The Fortune 500 average CEO age has risen something like 1 year per year for over a decade.

I just don’t understand this. This is occurring to you in 2020?? This compulsory intergenerational transfusion was initiated 28-48 years ago depending on how you want to count.

You are getting to this now. Here’s what happened: *3* generations below the Boomers are checked out. https://t.co/sAY47XeaMs

I) The Hispanic towns of Bishop, Palo Verde & la Loma, clockwise from Left. 1948.

II) Now.

IV) Walter O’Malley.

text: @Cyber_Spock I just said, screw it.
@LeonardChoong Some wild reads have been rejected. But I like singing. Given that I totally can’t sing. Also, I record @wineaccess while a bit tipsy. Hence the singing.
@crincled Yech.

@Jonathan_Blow That’s why I talk about:

A) Wanting to make money.

B) I don’t use all of them all the time. 

C) I like the ones that allow me to joke, scandalize l, throw in information and entertain you. I hate boring ad copy. Like everyone else.

That way you aren’t being snowed, hopefully.

I’m still figuring it out: Nobody loves ads for the sake of ads. But there would never have been a show without the ability to hit the ground running. Sponsors allowed me to do that so I don’t want to act too cool to acknowledge that they‘re mostly great products. At least by me.

But lastly, they‘ve paid for the show: The studio time. The post-production. My time. My share of the equipment costs. And you have had a fast forward button if you hate the ads. I admit I most enjoy working with companies who let me riff, risk & deviate from old staid ad-copy.

Also we turn down sponsors that don’t feel right. And lastly @FourSigmatic is really the only company that could get me to eat f^%#*ng mushrooms. The thought of non-truffle fungus makes me physically ill. So that is totally true.

Hope that answers the question about sponsors. https://t.co/MVfL9ciwFQ

I’m also not much of a consumer. So a lot of these have been things that have been most unexpected additions. 

Among the ones I really like and use: @BollAndBranch, @wineaccess, @expressvpn, Chili Technologies Ooler system, @skillshare, @LampsPlus etc.. And @Fender over decades. https://t.co/0fdO7mHjiB

Someone asked if I use the products of the companies that sponsor and allow me to do The Portal. The answer is not all of them...but about 70-80% of them after trying them out. I don’t know if that is normal for other shows, but they are mostly great additions to everyday life. https://t.co/YCSsoMAGXM

In short it was not beauty that lead physics astray. It was imbalance. Like a beautiful person going under the knife repeatedly to achieve perfection, in the end you see a monstrosity driven perversely and ironically by a sense of beauty because *total* beauty was neglected. End.

text: This is at the heart of my disagreement with @skdh. I am doubly contrarian with respect to QFT. I believe that many of the things they tried say were abstractly reasonable but clearly misinstanciated. To make their mere calculations beautiful, they were creating a hideous world.

When quantum field theorists talk about the ‘beauty’ of super-partners (e.g. gluinos, squarks) geometers and even nature herself seem to shrug. I quite honestly don’t disagree with the field theorists except for the naive aspect of their hope: they ignored other beauty standards.

A major problem with modern quantum theory is that it provided a surfeit of naive intuition about what to expect from nature largely untutored by geometry/algebra. That is, what is naively elegant to a quantum field theorist is not to nature or a geometer:
https://t.co/c1Uc1KIw0d
This is why we have academic freedom. It is wasted on almost all who have it. It is, however, essential for the *tiny* minority of people who use it.
